Firstly, before expanding, it must be said that this hotel targets a specifictype of Vegas tourist. If you are looking for a tranquil, beautiful, non-gaming and non-smoking place to stay, this is the place for you. Any reasonable individual, who may not be thrilled by the vibrant, crowdy and smoky atmosphere of the big casinos, will no doubt love this place. Upon our arrival, bell men welcomed us very kindly and took care of our bags. The modern decor and nice odor blew us away upon entering. Check in was quick and efficient. We were pleasantly upgraded to a larger Suite with full size kitchen, living room and large bathroom. Once in our room, a quick call to the bell desk assured the delivery of our luggage minutes afterwards. Also, the bell man took a few minutes to explain how the blinds worked, discussed a few services and told us pots and pans, as well as plates and utensils could be requeted at any time if needed. The room itself was beautiful. Since this was our first trip to Vegas, comparisons to other hotel rooms are off, but it must be said that one would need to be overly demanding to view this room with disregard. The bed was amazingly confortable with giant size pillows. Two 42 inch HD flatscreens with plenty of channels, (including McCarren flights) decorated the room. As opposed to many other reviews, everything worked fine: TV, Blinds, fridge, heating, lights...There is no issue whatsoever with light switches. There are plenty of them, true, but many control the same lights from different areas of the suite, in order to maximize the efficiency of its users. Also, hot water was never an issue. Water pressure in the shower was not the most powerful i've seen, but plenty enough to enjoy their huge showers. Being on the 6th floor, and facing the bellagio, the tram, and some construction, we were sure we would be disturbed by some noise. In fact, not a single time did we even notice some noise or any type of disturbances. We never waited for an elevator for more than 5 seconds, and it was great. The hotel charges a 15$ dollar resort fee per day as well as a small tax (about 2$), which is something they could include in the room rate from the start. But, in retrospective, this fee is not disproportionate with the available services such as free internet, free local and toll free calls, free bottles of water, free usage of the resort's gym, all of which would cost much more in other hotels if paid seperately. Also, position and access to this hotel was great for us. You can access the strip either via the bellagio, which is about a 5 to 10 min walk, the aria, and soon, once the cosmopolitan opens, a sidewalk, which is temporarily blocked by construction, will lead you to the strip in no time. Finally, the hotel's staff was great. Employees were very kind, saluting us constantly and always ready to answer some of our questions. They all seemed quite competent and we would be hard pressed to find them major flaws, based on our experience.The maids offered us great service and even complied to special demands for extra hand towels and so on. It seems to us both, that most of the negative reviews of this hotel were contrary to the experience we had during our 4 night stay. One can always find reasons to complain about a particular hotel, but I strongly feel that if you are looking for a quiet and beautiful place on the strip, and you have high but reasonable expectations, this will more than satisfy you. For a hotel which was opened for less than 2 months, it exceeded all our needs and expectations.

Reviews.Title: “Resort Fee”
Reviews.Author: TravTrip006
Reviews.Content: here is why I will not stay at a hotel with a resort fee: For your convenience a $15.00 daily resort fee will be added to your room account and includes the following hotel services: Internet access (in suite), local & 800 number phone calls, access to Fitness Center, in-room newspaper delivery, turndown service, and two bottles of water per day. All above was free and now they are adding a $15,00 fee. Nice try ---but no thanks.

Reviews.Title: “very swanky... here are some detailed TIPS”
Reviews.Author: LXNY
Reviews.Content: As with many others here, there were high expectations for the suites in this new complex. Knowing full well this place just opened, I didn't expect the service to be up to par, and it was quite obvious. Out of a 3 night stay, they even forgot to perform room service one morning. The accommodations were awesome, however. I had a CITY SUITE which provides a spectacular panoramic view over City Center, with strip views along the entire backdrop. This was an L-shaped "end unit", it practically gave 270 degrees of views. From the bedroom/bathroom side of the windows, you can see 60% of the Bellagio fountain! The The CITY SUITE also comes with a BOSCH washer and dryer, a full size refrigerator, and even a BOSCH dishwasher. Great if you have kids and are in Las Vegas for an extended stay. The couch in the living room was not very comfortable. I couldn't sit there long while watching TV. It is supposed to be a foldout bed, but I didn't try it out. Noise complaint - there is a vent fan in the kitchen, just above the fridge. It can't be turned on or off and it is quite annoying. You can't enjoy a quiet meal in the dining area, nor watch TV or sleep comfortably in the living room. I wonder if the front desk can control it as they can the automated lock on the mini-bar. Following up with complaints that there is no coffee maker, they might be installing KEURIG single-cup machines in every unit (as of Jan 10, 2010) One major annoyance is that there is no easy entry by car from FRANK SINATRA BLVD, the back road that can save you from having to drive up the busy, and often clogged STRIP/Las Vegas Blvd. The only true back way is from Harmon Ave on the other side of I-15. Even then, you have to ask the Aria valet staff to allow you to get past their pylons and over to Vdara. The $15 mandatory daily resort fee includes HIGH SPEED INTERNET/WIFI, access to FITNESS CENTER, daily delivery of Wall Street Journal, TURNDOWN SERVICE with 2 free mini bottles of water. Here are some tips to make the most of your stay: BRING YOUR OWN KEURIG coffee capsules/K-Cups (from your home or office): I believe they provide them in their mini-bar for a fee, so bring your own! There are NO STARBUCKS within City Center. The closest one (by walking) is at the entryway/down escalator to MONTE CARLO from ARIA, close to the TRAM stop there. ARRANGE FOR TURN-DOWN SERVICE: You get two free mini water bottles each day, and this is the only way to get them. Call in late afternoon, or before you leave for dinner. They automatically place them at your bedside tables. Shame on them for not letting you know this. FREE MINI WATER BOTTLES AT VALET PARKING (by ticket window): I noticed this during my stay. Not sure how long they'll be doing this. HIGH SPEED INTERNET: You can attach not just one device, but MULTIPLE laptops/handhelds. WiFi is available of course, and a single ethernet cable by the desk. Just enter your room number, and last name on the initial web page that will pop up. It supports finicky VPN connections by allowing you to select a "PUBLIC IP ADDRESS". WALKING OVER TO ARIA: Go out front entrance, walk along the path to the left that takes you straight there. Takes just 1 minute. WALKING OVER TO BELLAGIO or TRAM: as you exit elevators in Vdara, make left down the lobby (opposite check-in), then another left that takes you down a corridor that leads you to Bellagio and City Center TRAM. Less than 5 min. SELF PARKING option 1: you can easily park over at the Bellagio Self-Park and walk over. Drive on the STRIP to main Bellagio entrance, look for SELF-PARK signs towards left. Take elevators to CASINO, walk past the check-in area, then past Bellagio Garden and you'll see signs leading you to VDARA. About 5 min. SELF-PARKING option 2 (especially if you have luggage/groceries and don't want to traverse the busy CASINO): park at the ARIA's self-park garage, by driving up CITY CENTER DRIVE from the STRIP. Look for signs to your left as you drive up the ramp. Once parked, take the free CITY CENTER tram. As you walk out of the garage and towards escalators to CASINO, follow TRAM signs to your immediate left. Go through automated mirrored glass doors. There will be escalators to take you to platform. You will be at the "Monte Carlo/Aria" station, it then takes you to "Crystals" mall, and then get off at last stop "Bellagio/Vdara". Take ELEVATOR down (not escalator) and it will put you within footsteps of the VDARA. You can take escalator, but it's a much longer way. (REVERSE these steps to get back to Aria Self-Park.) CVS and WALGREENS within easy reach: If you need snacks & sundries, CVS is just at the foot of the property on Las Vegas Blvd. Walgreens is not much further, but across the street. It may be easier to take the CITY CENTER TRAM to CRYSTALS mall and walk out to the street from there. DRIVING TO VDARA: The only entry to VDARA is accessible from the STRIP/Las Vegas Blvd. (Do not go up CITY CENTER DRIVE). At HARMON BLVD. (You can also get there from WEST of I-15 by taking Harmon Blvd, but it places you at the back entrance to ARIA and you have to ask the valet staff to move pylons to your right that will allow you to navigate the rotunda over to the VDARA.)

Reviews.Title: “Nice..but could be better”
Reviews.Author: littlecookiemonster
Reviews.Content: When took a cab from the airport to the hotel on x'mas day around noon or so. We tried to check-in but the guy from the front desk said check in is at 3PM, so we dropped off our luggage to the bell desk and headed out to check around the other hotels around the area. We went back at 3PM to check-in...only to find that there were around 20 people trying to check-in. The line-up to check in took more than half an hour. However, they were nice enough to offer us bottles of water while we were lining up. We did not get any upgrades or anything since I overheard the person in front of us was asking and had to pay extra each night. I only asked to get a better view or a suite on a higher floor. The lady at the front desk told me that we were going to get a room on the 35th floor which is the highest floor that is open as construction is still going on the levels above us. When we finally got our key to the room, we tried to take the elevator to the 35th floor. At that time, I think they just opened the floor that day and there was something wrong with the system, so there was no access to go to the 35th floor. It was fixed about 10 minutes after since other people have been complaining before. I was quite satisfied with the view that we got in our room... our room faced the south side of the strip and we also saw the Aria hotel. One thing I found pretty neat about the room was the curtains on the window. There was a control near by the kitchen which allowed you to adjust the "shade" or "Blackout" of the curtains. However, I must have to say the lights were a little hard to manage, it was like a trial and error thing. One thing I thought was surprising is that there are no toothbrushes or toothpastes provided. I asked the bell boy when he came to deliver our luggages, it seemed like he was caught by surprised that I asked if there were toothbrushes and he directed us to the convenience store at Bellagio to get one. I must have to say the furnishings are quite nice...the bed and sheets were very comfortable. I also liked the shower and had no problems with hot water. They also have a scale in the washroom which I thought was quite neat...but never used. I also like the back-lit mirror in the washroom for me to do my make-up. The towel rack that they have was also quite convenient. I was quite upset when there was no internet in my room. I had tried to go on with my iphone and it said that there was something wrong with the gateway and I should contact for assistance, I called the front desk and they directed me to some other line. They told me that they would ask an engineer to test the spots and would be coming in shortly. Since my bf was still sleeping and didn't want to wake him up, I asked if they could come up at 8:00-8:30AM. I also specifically asked if i needed to call again to make sure someone would come up. They told me no....No one came until 9:00..and when I opened the door, I was kind of surprised to find out it was just housekeeping. They ring the doorbell everyone morning to see if cleaning is required. So be sure to turn on the lights beside the door if you don't want to be disturbed! When I left my room for the day, i dropped by the front desk and complained to them that I called earlier and no one came.I also told them I had to leave for the day and will talk to them when I get back. I went back during the afternoon because I had to pick up some stuff. I went to the business office asking them about the internet..and somehow it managed to work afterwards. On our second night back, we bought 2 bottles of water since the ones provided by vdara are relatively small. When we came back from housekeeping the 3rd day, they didn't replace our water bottles as they saw that we still had some left. They didn't replace our waters since that day. Just a side note, for people who like to drink hot water.. I could not find a kettle in the room. We booked our grand canyon tour from the hotel. We first went through concierge, and he then directed us to the bell desk. Both of them are very helpful and were really nice. When i checked out, we had to go through the check-in desk again..which I thought was a bit of a hassle. The girl asked me how my stay was. I told her about how I was quite surprised that there were no toothbrushes...her response was did I asked housekeeping. I told her i did talk to to the bell desk..and her response was kind of like "oh". So i was quite confused if we were supposed to get it or not... I also mentioned about the internet issue that I had...But she didn't seem to say too much. Well anyway, I looked at the pamphlet she gave me and inside it said there was a link to satisfaction email. It was no where to be found. So i looked up the website to email them. They responded and told me that their system was not working. They also addressed me as "Mr" instead of "Ms" or "Miss" when it clearly shows my name is a girl. Well I wrote them an email identifying the issues that I had and was not satisfied with and expected more from a 4-5 star hotel they claimed they were. I never got a response from them, but it looks like they credited my resort fee. Now would I go back again? Maybe...after they worked out their management a bit better...but i'd probably give Aria a try next time since there are so many other hotels to try out along the strip.

Reviews.Title: “BEWARE”
Reviews.Author: TaraDuisburg
Reviews.Content: In November I booked two suites at "Vdara" (one week in February) and I had to pay about 300 USD by Creditcard. About three weeks ago I cancelled my reservation because of the bad reviews of the tripadvisor members. I was very astonished to learn that it is not possible to cancel by their webside. I sent two E-mails, there was no response and the money was not refunded. Two weeks ago I phoned AE to refund the money. They as well tried to contact "Vdara", no response as well. I do not know if I will get my money back. So be sure you do not want to cancel your reservation.

Reviews.Title: “Atypical Vegas hotel, sleek and modern.”
Reviews.Author: Kousnzca
Reviews.Content: Not much to add onto the thorough and objective reviews below that are pretty much accurate. I stayed there for 3 nights/4 days with my husband and was impressed with the modern, simple decor and vibe. I appreciated that I could get away from the typical Vegas casino atmosphere and the smell of cigarettes. We were on the 42nd floor with great views of the Strip and surrounding areas - Rio and The Palms to the left, Paris and The Bellagio (including the Fountains!) to the right. Rooms were clean and well-designed; the lighting is a bit complex but tolerable and we didn't find any problems with the water pressure of the shower. The only two negatives would be -the $15 resort fee per day, which was pretty much useless to us -the location of the hotel: it was too far off from the Strip. Vdara is connected to the Bellagio and yes, there is a tram, but it is definitely a more inconvenient location compared to so many other hotels. I would return to the Vdara and recommend to a friend only if a good deal was availble; otherwise, there are better hotels that are more conveniently located.

Reviews.Title: “Nice niche, but nothing special”
Reviews.Author: bizkilla
Reviews.Content: The Vdara offers a unique aspect to the hustle and bustle of the center "Strip." It is essentially, or was atleast designed to be, a studio/condo/timeshare-type property located in the CityCenter megacomplex (and now is a hotel; probably due to the real estate crash/economy and the leftover investors wanting to recoup some of their losses). It is a green-friendly, smoke-free hotel, conveniently located in the center of it all. At this time it is new and very clean. The deluxe room is spacious and elegantly decorated with contemporary simplistic furniture and minimal decor. The wood finish was nice. The kitchenette was also nice, but unnecessary. The bed was comfortable and the dual television sets were a nice tough. We were on the 12th floor and our view was'nt very much. We could see the mountains beyond and the Rio and Palms properties and on the other side there was a partial view of Paris and the back of the Bellagio which looked like some sort of loading area, not much at all. I quess I should have asked for a better view or a higher room. The bathroom was a bit less to be desired. There was only one sink, no big deal, but two is better than one. The tub, although it looks very nice is just too small. It may be suitable for people 5'6" or shorter. Almost impossible to fit a couple hoping for an intimate experience. The floor is very slippery, would recommend sacrifycing some towels as mats. And the shower pressure has now reached infamous proportions as just about every review online tells of how weak it is. There is a setting you can change it to but it does not add much if anything at all. The staff at the hotel is rookie. At check-in, the representative fumbled around with our identification, our room keys and our money. She made very very minimal eye contact and seemed uncomfortable, maybe it was her first day; but still. The concierge seemed to make lame recommendations and didnt know where a chain steakhouse was despite being located directly across the street from CityCenter (S&W; I would avoid if I were you, try Craftsteak instead). In addition, the toilet paper on our arrival was so low that it ran out the second time it was needed. On one day they didnt replenish the water. On another, housekeeping did not knock and just entered and announced "housekeeping." Two minutes later, someone rings the bell twice, waits 10 seconds and enters the room. I jump up and say "excuse me", she just tells me that I should press the do not disturb button if I do not wish to be bothered. And on a bit of a disturbing note, on one day, when housekeping came in to do their routine, they went a bit too far IMO, they folded and therefore touched my wifes intimates and folded them on our bed, even though that portion of our belongings was tucked away in a corner and not even touched on the previous housekeping visits. My wife was freaked out as she claims that items were removed from her luggage. We called to complain and got our resort fees back (currently $15 pernight + tax) We simply just wanted fresh towels and a made bed, maybe we should have communicated our desires beforehand. I have nothing to say about the restaurant as I did not try. It looked kind of sad as business seemed very slow and servers were outside fishing for guests instead of being on a floor running wild providing service. Bellagio is just a few minutes away and is connected by a walkway. Once inside you go down an escalator and go thru a few hallways before entering the lobby. On the other side is Aria, which is even quicker to get into. Both of course offer something unique in their own right and this is where Vdara's niche can really be appreciated. When you go thru these other places, it is just pure Vegas. There are just herds and herds and herds of people. Hundreds and thousands of people. Cigar smoke and stores and bright lights and casino noises and did I mention the hundreds and thousands of people. But in Vdara, its just a a nice calming, environment. Its a break from all that you see out in this concrete bright light jungle. We toured Vegas by foot most of the time and this hotels proximity to the center was nice, however the hotel is a bit tucked inside the complex so just a few additional steps will be needed if you plan on the same strategy. Overall, I give them a 4/5. They did not really wow me with anything special. Being a new place they made some common mistakes they will have to improve on if they desire to be a true 5-star hotel. Their niche is a good one and they should be able to compete. Im not sure what the properties long-term goals are but this a tough city to compete in considering they do not have gambling. But if they can turn 1st timers into repeats, they could do very very well. I greatly enjoyed my last Vegas trip and am sad it has come to an end, a review is always good closure and I encourage all of you in the future to share your experiences and reminisce. I would recommend and would stay again for the right price.

Reviews.Title: “A very nice stay”
Reviews.Author: steve100
Reviews.Content: I enjoyed the entire experience. The staff was great, the room was perfect with a very comfortable bed a workable room layout. I liked the separation from all the sensory overload of the casino hotels. The lobby was very visual in a subtle way. My wife is an art major and loved the colors, the textures and the shapes on the hotel proper and the room. We walked through the other resorts and saw people waiting for check-in, the concierge, It was a treat to be greeted with a smile, and asked if there was anything I needed or wanted special. A big yes if you ask me

Reviews.Title: “Wonderful unique option; very hard to get to”
Reviews.Author: TheatreTraveler
Reviews.Content: I booked this hotel before it opened, so I knew I was going to be a pioneer. And I was prepared for some small problems (particularly after reading the previous reviews here). While there are, indeed, a few snags, overall this is a great property. People have complained about the lack of shops and restaurants and casinos on property -- but this is exactly WHY I love Vdara. It's amazing to have all of the Vegas insanity steps away, but return to a peaceful, quiet, smoke-free oasis at the end of the day. Perhaps people who voiced those complaints didn't read the hotel's description when they booked, since this is the very concept behind Vdara. It would be nice if the hotel was closer to the many nearby options (more on that later), but I didn't miss having them on-site (though a Starbucks and a small grab-and-go cafe in the lobby would be a help). I believe this was slated to be a condo building, and when the recession hit they changed plans -- which explains some of the quirks, but also the unique, tranquil vibe here. The rooms are great, the decor is groovy, and the light switches really aren't ALL that complicated (though I'll admit that labels or a quick instruction card would be a huge help). My one pet peeve with the lighting is that you can't turn off the bedside lights from anywhere near the bed -- so you have to get up and go to the kitchen (where the switch is located) and then go back to bed in semi-darkness. As many people have noted, the water pressure in the shower is somewhat limited -- but it's bearable. Given that the water pressure in the sinks and bathtub are great I'm assuming this is a choice and undoubtedly has to do with the building's "Green" certification. Annoying, but understandable (and for a noble cause). I found the staff friendly, the rooms great, and the views impressive (I believe that the "view" rooms face north, but I faced the other direction and loved my view). They're running specials right now since it's new -- and if you can get a good deal it's worth it. The $15 resort fee is annoying if you're not going to use the services -- but for me it was great. I rely on internet when I'm away and most hotels on the Strip charge $15 (or more) for the internet alone. At Vdara, the $15 fee gets you internet PLUS access to the fitness center, which is a unique perk (every hotel in Vegas that I know of requires you to pay hefty day fees to use the gym), which I took advantage of. The gym itself is very clean and the equipment is great. It's on the small side by comparison to a real gym (or even the other gym/spas on the Strip), but huge by comparison to a free hotel gym. Oddly, the "resort fee" only gets you access to the gym itself -- if you want to use the locker room/spa area it's another $25. I asked for a tour and was not impressed. It's pretty, and stocked with tons of Aveda products and other amenities. But it's really just a nice locker room with a jacuzzi, steam and sauna. If that's your thing, skip the upsell and head next door to either the Bellagio (same $25 gets you access to their bigger/better gym and a larger/more impressive spa area) or Aria ($30 gets you access to their huge gym, plus a large spa area with everything at Vdara plus meditation rooms, heated pool deck, etc.). The only thing that's irritating about this hotel is the location. It's a great location in that it's in the heart of the strip. But it's so tucked away and hidden, it's like the entire hotel is in a witness protection program. It's virtually inaccessible by foot, unless you cut through the Aria or Bellagio (or take a creepy stairway to a side street that looks like a loading dock). To get there by car, you take a barely-marked ramp off the side street and then go through a maze of driveways to get to the entrance. It's like the hotel was shoved into an odd parcel of land behind something else -- but it was built from scratch with the rest of the complex!!! Who on earth designed this?!?! I guess when it was going to be a condo they wanted private exclusivity -- but now that it's a hotel, at least some bigger/bolder signage would seriously help matters. It's honestly like they don't want anyone to find it. Overall I think this is a great find in Vegas, and definitely has a unique bent that separates it from the other higher-end properties on the Strip. If you're looking for the quintessential Vegas experience, this is not the hotel for you. But if you're looking for an oasis of civilized calm, get thee to Vdara.

Reviews.Title: “Awesome time!”
Reviews.Author: rvajda
Reviews.Content: I was taking my girlfriend to Vegas for her birthday present (both first-timers) and could not wait. After reading reviews on tripadvisor I was unsure if this hotel was ready to be open yet. We arrived early on a Friday morning about 10pm but no rooms were available so we were told to come back at noon to check and we checked our bags with the bell service who were very nice! So we went to brunch and came back at noon and were told a room was available where I was able to pick a preference in which room we stayed in. I recommend asking for a room on one of the higher floors with views of the Bellagio fountains. Great mountain, Bellagio, Paris views. The room was extremely nice and like other users who stated switches were hard to use and confusing I found that to be laugh, after using them once you knew how to do it although not all conveniently located. Bed was amazing, shower and tub also amazing, and great robes. A safe is located in the closet. Only real problems we had was that the tv would freeze every now and then. The ipod connections can only be used as chargers right now but they are ordering the extensions to have the music play through the tv. Other then that the room was everything I thought it would be and better. Everyone who worked in the hotel was great and very friendly. Ask for deals going on and they will have discounts available. Walkway to Bellagio was used everyday. Closes at midnight? Not sure why. Great experience and would stay again! Ask for the view!

Reviews.Title: “Never again”
Reviews.Author: stefyItaly
Reviews.Content: We reserved our room in september and when we arrived it was at the 15th floor with a terrible pool in construction view. The sink didn't work, the shadows didn't obscure the room, the alarm clock or the phone woke up us every morning for stupid mistakes of the housekeeping. We had to pay 15 dollars a day for a resort fee that we didn't know and this would include a wallstreet journal each day ( who asked for it) the wifi ( it worked just for two days in 10 days total) and 2 bottles of water. We had these free bottles of water just the first day, so when the third night my boyfriend woke up thirsty during the night, we had finished the water of the minibar ( and they didn't replace them) so he drunk the water from the sink ( in Italy our water is good), there was no warning about how bad was that water...ther result was vomite fever and diarrhea for three days.... We tried to ask for a late check up and an arrogant staff replied us that if we were late they would charge us half day cost... We stayed at the Encore some months before and we missed it so much.Please don't do the same mistake, forgive me for my english,but I wanted you to know to avoid this place.

Reviews.Title: “Inconsistant Through & Through”
Reviews.Author: Sibonile
Reviews.Content: Had I not read the other Trip Advisors reviews before going I would have been royally pissed at so many of the problems, instead of just moderately pissed. We stayed at Vdara Dec. 30-Jan.4 (6 days, 5 nights) with the plan of partying our butts off for New Years. Two girlfriends of mine and I packed into their standard room, with me on the pullout bed. We found a deal for $139 a night, and for it being over NYE we thought that was a great. HOWEVER, (and here come the list of problems) 1) Our reservation SOMEHOW had been cancelled and had I not brought the physical printout of the reservation we would have been screwed. 2) We were placed in a room on the 15th floor by the dumpsters, there was ZERO cell reception for AT&T iPhone users and noise at 7am drove us bonkers (we switched rooms to the 25th floor and it was better but there were still cell reception issues). 3) I asked for a 7am wake-up call that never came and so I missed my $400 tour and caused a ton of headache. 4) Turndown service?? Apparently they don't know what that is because we asked for it every night and the most they ever did was flip the corner of one of the beds down and leave...huh? 5) Towels. If there are 3 people staying in the room WHY would you only leave 2 sets of towels EVERYDAY even after being asked for 3 sets of towels EVERYDAY 6) Toilet. It got stopped up twice and the second time they never came to fix it. 7) Heat. The engineer came up and gave some cockamamie excuse for why the heat wouldn't go higher than 75. No excuses please, just FIT IT! 8) What's up with the light switches? You have to flip everything on and off 7x before you get the right settings. 9) The lighting sucks, everywhere in the room it sucks. 10) and the biggest gripe of all... if upon checking out your receptionist asks, "how was your stay" and I say not so great and explain why, at that point YOU SHOULD DO SOMETHING! ANYTHING! SAY WHATEVER YOU WANT TO QUELL MY ANGER BUT DON'T PUT YOUR HEAD DOWN MUTTER INCOHERENTLY, HAND ME THE RECEIPT AND TELL ME HAVE A NICE DAY!!!! WHAT???!??!?!!! Oh, I was through with the hotel at that point. Other pains in the butt (which many others have commented on), include: distance from reasonably priced food, distance from the strip, unhelpful concierge, dishes/silverware not being readily available, never any bath salts. Some positives: Robin Leech of "Lifestyles of the Rich & Famous" was staying there which was funny, the hotel is quiet and smells nice, non-smoking, the room service breakfast was very pretty (the OJ was bitter though), our bellhop was helpful. There are many other places to stay in Vegas and if you have the option of staying elsewhere I'd do it. I'm glad I got to try out the CityCenter but now know it's not that big of a deal.

Reviews.Title: “Most over rated hotel I have stayed at with astonishingly arrogant staff”
Reviews.Author: Rugame4
Reviews.Content: This hotel has been the worst place I've stayed at on this 4 week holiday across this country. Arrogant staff, very low water pressure in the showers. Terribly low lighting in the rooms and a complete lack of ambience to the whole place. Concierge that are very unhelpful to say the least.

Reviews.Title: “Serenity of Las Vegas”
Reviews.Author: xg3579
Reviews.Content: Stayed there from Jan 2nd to 7th. Very quiet hotel... very different than typical Las Vegas lobbies. I arrived at 11:00pm, checked in.. painless process, couldn't get a upgrade, but the suite was nice anyways. My Suite was at the 20th floor overlooking the back of Bellagio with a slight view of the Eiffel Tower. Not great, but decent. Previous reviews were right, there were no plates, cups or anything. You can hear the trucks beeping at night, never woke me up at night but was kind of suprise with the stuffs going on even at 4-5am. They do give you two free bottles of water every day and room uses Aveda products (Conditioner, shampoo, Body bath, Hand soap) Swimming pool was locked off due to construction when i was there. WIFI included in your $15/day room fee, wired connection the table. The TVs do have media centre, so you can plug in a HDMI cable or USB key to watch movies. It is a 1min walk to Aria. There you will find casino, buffet and all your needs,it is a 2-3min walk to Bellagio. Those are your only entrance to the hotel by foot. If you have friends staying at Aria and vdara, is best to get drop off at vdara, for Aria has two seperate drop off point, one shared with vdara and the other by itself (and you will have to walk through the casino and outside to get back to vdara) Citycentre was somewhat open, LV and Tiffanny was open, but quiet. The bank club is in there, seems packed on saturday night. Would i stay there again? Yes, but not for my next trip to Vegas. The location makes it inconvenient to access the strip quickly, lack of casino and restaurant also mean you have to walk or cab everywhere. If it is your first time to Vegas, and want to experience the thrill of Vegas, skip this hotel. If you have been there many times and looking for comfort of home and excitement that is available minutes away, vdara is your choice. ps. No shopping at vdara either..

Reviews.Title: “Just a great experience after a few hic cups”
Reviews.Author: scottishtommy
Reviews.Content: lets start with the hic cups,arrived at hotel allocated a room on the 24th floor.The room hadnt been cleaned.On complaining re allocated to the 38th floor (highest available floor ready at this time)Waited after 3 phone calls for 3 hours for my luggage to arrive.After 26 hours travelling from Scotland via Amsterdam and minniapolis last thing i needed was the valet to be so long bringing up our luggage. Now to the great experience, on 38th floor directly over looking the Ballagio and her fountains beautiful view and a great vantage point to oversee the fireworks and the hustle bustle of the Las Vegas strip. Read a few reviews of people complaining about the long walks to the strip.As im a lil on the large side (well lets say built for comfort rather than speed lol)i was a lil apprehensive of staying at the hotel.After being at the hotel for a few days these fears were unfounded the hotel was in for me a great location 10mins from the strip with 3 ways to get there via the ballagio ,through Aria or a short walk out past Crystals to Planet Hollywood there is a tram to Crystals or Monti carlo but its quicker to walk so for me tram waste of time. Great to get back to this hotel as all rooms are only minutes from the main lobby as opposed to 30-45 mins like the venetian and mgm grand.Ive stayed in numerous hotels on the strip over the years and this by far was my favourite the non smoking non gaming side i enjoyed probably saved me losing a lot more than i did.Room service was nice.Found the maid service a lil over zealous with numerous messages to my room most days saying they hadnt cleaned the room and they needed access but every time the room had already been cleaned . On the whole great hotel great location great room lay outs but then again the room i eventually stayed in was brand new never before used .What i will add is that for a new hotel thats only opened a few weeks the first room they offered my looked like a rock group had stayed in it and trashed the place.Tommy fae Scotland best 10 days in Vegas by far [--]

Reviews.Title: “Great potential but not quite there yet”
Reviews.Author: hangbo
Reviews.Content: We stayed for 5 nights from Jan. 1-6. We had to wait until 3:30 to check in, but we did get a room on 43rd floor with great views. There is a very modern feel to the room. Bed was extremely comfortable, and the blackout shades allowed for sleeping in very late without the sun waking us up. The refrigerator didn't work and the minibar wasn't stocked, but a person from maintenance brought us up the drinks we requested on the house to make up for minibar being empty. We only got the free bottles of water once during the entire stay despite having evening turndown service at least three times. Service from housekeeping (Emanuel) and maintenance (Harris) were very helpful when I became ill during the stay from some bad food one night. Housekeeping during the day though seemed spotty - our shampoo, conditioner, soap,etc. weren't always restocked. Bath salts appeared on our 3rd night but weren't replaced. These are things that I expect will be ironed out over time. In general though the attitude of most of the staff seemed to be very helpful. Location isn't ideal. We're still debating if we'd stay here again because of location - in general loved the room but the location makes it difficult to get around.

Reviews.Title: “In serious need of new management”
Reviews.Author: shinrai
Reviews.Content: This place is beautiful and has potential but because of some of the staff our stay was fouled. The place was opened in a hurry so the staff is not properly trained or screened! (opening was rushed for this multi-billion dollar overrun development). Things (electronics and money) were taken from our room during housekeeping and management did not respond to our complaints. A room safe was not available. No hot water on the first night of our 5 night stay. No plates/cups/utensils etc. in our suite so it's not a true condo/suite hotel as of yet. Bath tub drain did not work properly etc. The detail is not there and can be compared to a upper class hotel in China. Currently there are no customer comment cards available?! However the hotel's fitness center and fitness staff are worthy of compliments and are top notch. I would recommend staying at the better known 5 star locations on the strip.

Reviews.Title: “All dressed up with nowhere to go”
Reviews.Author: CouldTravelEverlong
Reviews.Content: On Vdara: 1. They need to fix the TV systems. 1st room we got (all rooms very modern and pretty), the TV was broken. The moved us to a second room, only to see large red stains on the carpet, 5 total, all around the bed. Not something I want to walk on barefoot.. 3rd times the charm? Not really. Upgraded to a suite to make up for it. A half hour into the room, TV broke. It took them 45 minutes to send up someone to fix it, and then, it broke again 30 minutes after he left. 2. Don't go if you plan on showering. There was absolutely the worst shower I have ever taken. Took 30 minutes to get hot water, seriously, 30 minutes. (after the TV debacle, didn't want to call down again). I figured lots of guests must be getting ready at the same time, no excuse, but whatever. Nope, I took 3 miserable showers at 3 different times of the day. NO HOT WATER, when you did get the water going, the water pressure was a joke. I mean, really, it was BAD. Took forever to get the shampoo and conditioner out. At one point i considered rinsing off in the sink, it was really that bad. 3. No direct access to the sister hotel Aria (where the casino is located and entry to the mall). You have to walk outside, across the valet and street area and then back inside. I thought this was a huge mistake on their part. It was freezing and SO inconvenient. I would think a tunnel or something would be a no brainer. Encore/Wynn are connected, Mandalay/THEhotel are connected, wth? There is a tunnel to Bellagio though. Oh and there was no pool when we went. In relation to City Center: 4. The tram, seriously, what were they thinking??? We took it from Crystals to Bellagio. 1st of all, no street access. You have to leave the hotel, walk outside, into Aria, leave Aria, go into the mall, go up 2 or 3 escalators, or the oddly placed elevators, and then go outdoors again to get to the tram. What were they thinking with this design?? 5. Crystals Mall, wow. There is no flow to the design. Dead spaces, no staff, can't get to the elevators or escalators easily at all. There is some great visual aspects, but I can't believe how obviously bad the design is. 6. The whole City Center entrance looks like an airport. No landscaping, just concrete ramps and signage. 7. The Aria casino was dark as some people mentioned, I tend to like dark decor, but there was something I couldn't put my finger on, it wasn't warm/inviting at all. (It was a little airportish in some areas, but that wasn't even it.) A few more design blunders/oversights here too. Like the taxi line and Haze nightclub. You can tell they didn't really take into consideration people waiting to get in or lines for events, so they just kinda winged it last minute. People are crammed behind the escalators to that floor. There is no staff back there, and minimal light. When we were there it was covered in trash people had discarded while they waiting to get into a concert. The only place ot get a taxi in the whole hotel/casino, is blocked by this line of people and the front of Haze. You have to literally go through a maze of people between the line and the club to get to the cab line. Then once you are there, you walk to walk outside and down about 40 yards to the cabs, it looks more like an alley than anything else. On the whole: It's bad design with even worse execution. I left wanting to hug Steve Wynn, and wondering how MGM made such a huge mistake with this whole project.

HotelInfo.Name: Vdara Hotel & Spa
HotelInfo.Address: 2600 W. Harmon Avenue, Las Vegas, NV 89109
